I've been researching the idea of Unconditional Universal Basic Income since 2013. Here's a collection of findings I've compiled from various UBI experiments and studies of cash transfer programs around the world.

This will be a VERY LONG and ongoing thread focused entirely on empirical evidence. 🧵

images.alt:
OBSERVED EFFECTS OF UBI

No significant reduction in labor supply (38 studies meta-analysis)

Increased self-employment (301%) and part-time employment (17%)

Slight decrease in alcohol and tobacco use (31 studies meta-analysis)

New mothers extend their maternity leaves

Birth weights improve due to better maternal nutrition

Graduation rates and educational outcomes improve

Hospitalization rates decline (8.5%)

Crime goes down (15%–42%) especially illegal hunting (95%)

Domestic violence decreases (30%–51%)

Trust increases (13% in politicians | 6% in other people)

Home ownership rates increase (17%–26%)

Food security increases as does consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables

Improved cognitive functioning (43%) and personality traits (31%)

Savings go up, debts go down


Source: scottsantens

external.description: With 2030 rapidly approaching and the EU’s Digital Decade target of 20 million ICT professionals still out of reach, urgent action is needed. Bringing together youth education, civil society, digital industry and government, this initiative implements innovative approaches to digitally upskill young Europeans. The vision is to build a sustainable, scalable digital education and upskilling movement that empowers every young person to embrace digital technologies and pursue fulfilling digital careers. By reimagining and relaunching EU Code Week with a new mandate, this effort drives real change in digital education, aiming to significantly increase youth engagement in digital careers and unite the entire digital skills ecosystem to close Europe’s digital skills gap.

external.description: Happy Raksha Bandhan Wishes: Raksha Bandhan, the special day to celebrate the love and affection between brothers and sisters, will be celebrated across India on Aug. 9. On this auspicious day, sisters tie a rakhi, a sacred thread, on their brothers’ wrists. On the other hand, brothers pledge to protect and cherish their sisters. The Raksha Bandhan celebrations are marked by the exchange of gifts, sweets and traditional cuisines as well as family gatherings.  As per the Hindu calendar, Raksha Bandhan is celebrated on the Purnima Tithi, or full moon day, in the month of Shravan.

Elyse Betters Picaro / ZDNET ZDNET's key takeaways: OpenAI launched ChatGPT customization updates. Users can choose chat color and personality. All users (even free) can now access Advanced Voice Mode. OpenAI…

external.description: Elyse Betters Picaro / ZDNET ZDNET's key takeaways: OpenAI launched ChatGPT customization updates. Users can choose chat color and personality. All users (even free) can now access Advanced Voice Mode. OpenAI is having one of its biggest product launch weeks, releasing its highly anticipated open-source models, gpt-oss-120b and gpt-oss-20b, and GPT-5. Buried within the deluge of the large language models (LLMs) are helpful ChatGPT features that add customization options that could make the ChatGPT experience more enjoyable.

record.text:
Harvard Reveals $116 Million Investment in BlackRock Bitcoin ETF

In brief Harvard University and Brown both have Bitcoin exposure. Regulatory filings show that the top universities bought positions via BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust. A number of top institutions have done the same thing since…

external.description: In brief Harvard University and Brown both have Bitcoin exposure. Regulatory filings show that the top universities bought positions via BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust. A number of top institutions have done the same thing since the historic approval of Bitcoin ETFs. Top universities Harvard and Brown are the latest institutions to buy exposure to Bitcoin, according to regulatory filings.  The Harvard Management Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the university, has a $116 million position in BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust, a 13F form filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission shows.
external.title: Harvard Reveals $116 Million Investment in BlackRock Bitcoin ETF

value.text: Alemanha suspende envio de armas para Israel que possam ser usadas em Gaza após governo israelense aprovar nova ofensiva .

external.description:
A Alemanha anunciou nesta sexta-feira a suspensão das exportações de equipamentos militares para Israel que possam ser empregados na Faixa de Gaza. A medida foi tomada após o governo israelense aprovar um plano para assumir o controle da Cidade de Gaza, parte de uma estratégia de ampliação da ofensiva no território palestino. Merz afirmou que é “cada vez mais difícil entender” como a ofensiva militar israelense contribuiria para atingir objetivos legítimos. 
— Nestas circunstâncias, o governo alemão não autorizará nenhuma exportação de equipamentos militares que possa ser utilizada na Faixa de Gaza até novo aviso — declarou.
A medida amplia o distanciamento de Berlim em relação a ações de Israel no enclave palestino, em meio à crescente pressão internacional contra a operação em Gaza. E também marca uma mudança de postura do governo, que, até pouco tempo, evitava emitir críticas públicas ao governo de Benjamin Netanyahu. No mês passado, o ministro das Relações Exteriores alemão, Johann Wadephul, afirmou que “o país continuará a apoiar Israel, inclusive com o fornecimento de armas”.
Israel é o 15º maior importador de armas do planeta e tem usado muitos dos equipamentos comprados no exterior, especialmente dos EUA e da Alemanha, em Gaza. E enquanto essas nações se opõem a um embargo armamentista, especialistas ouvidos pelo GLOBO apontam que as vendas podem violar normas internacionais.
Os EUA, principais aliados dos israelenses e responsáveis por 66% das exportações, aprovaram pacotes bilionários desde o retorno de Donald Trump à Casa Branca — o republicano também abandonou uma regra de seu antecessor, Joe Biden, que exigia dos compradores o compromisso de que os armamentos não seriam usados em atos contrários à lei internacional. Washington não reconhece a jurisdição da Corte Internacional de Justiça (CIJ).
Em atualização.
external.title: Alemanha suspende envio de armas para Israel que possam ser usadas em Gaza após governo israelense aprovar nova ofensiva

2. Syria (41%)
3. Laos (40%)
4. Switzerland (39%)
5. Iraq, Serbia, Canada (35%)

record.text:
Does anyone know how much #Portland has paid out already to victims of police officer Erik Kammerer? And if he's not on the Brady list, why not?

https://www.oregonlive.com/crime/2025/08/portland-councilors-grill-police-chief-while-approving-375m-settlement-in-fatal-shooting-of-unarmed-man.html

external.title:
Immanueal Clark Portland police shot Immanueal Clark, 30, in the lower back on Nov. 19, 2022, as he was running from police. He died two days later at OHSU Hospital.Courtesy of FamilyBy Zaeem Shaikh | The Oregonian/OregonLive
Several Portland City Council members pointedly questioned Police Chief Bob Day Thursday as they approved a $3.75 million settlement with the family of an unarmed man shot and killed by an officer who mistook him for a robbery suspect. 

They wanted to know why Day did not agree with an internal investigator who found Officer Christopher Sathoff had violated police policy in the 2022 shooting of 30-year-old Immanueal Clark.

They asked why it took more than 20 minutes to get medical help for Clark. 

Day repeated what he has said before – he described Clark’s death as a tragedy and said he relied on the findings of the officer’s commander and top Police Bureau officials who found that Sathoff believed Clark was armed and reaching for a gun. He said Clark’s death “should anger us” and it does for him.

“I’m required by law to take that anger and that frustration and that loss and approach my decision from an objectively reasonable standard,” Day said during a City Council meeting.

Council members unanimously approved the settlement – one of the biggest in a shooting by Portland police.

Council President Elana Pirtle-Guiney said she struggled to understand how “the response to a robbery is losing your life.”

“I want to say very clearly to Manny’s family, I am sorry that this happened,” Pirtle-Guiney said. “This should not have happened.”

Sathoff shot and killed Clark about 12:40 a.m. on Nov. 19, 2022, as Clark ran from officers who had approached his car in a church parking lot in the 2900 block of Southeast Steele Street. Police mistakenly believed his speeding sedan had been at the scene of an armed robbery outside a Super Deluxe fast-food restaurant on Southeast 50th Avenue and Powell Boulevard.

Day found that Sathoff had complied with the Police Bureau’s use-of-force policy that states force must be “objectively reasonable” in the circumstances known by an officer at the time and not judged with the benefit of hindsight. 

The policy is based on the Graham standard for judging excessive force claims established by the U.S. Supreme Court. It says police departments should consider the severity of the suspected crime, whether a person was resisting or trying to run away and whether officers believed the person posed a threat to them or others. 

In the case involving Clark, Day said Sathoff was responding to a report of an armed robbery, a violent crime. He also said when officers tried to stop Clark and others in the car, some of the occupants ran away, “which made the situation more dangerous and unpredictable.” 

Because the call involved the report of a weapon and fleeing suspects, Day told City Council members that the officer had reason to believe Clark might be armed and willing to use force.

He cited points made by other Police Bureau supervisors that other officers shared a similar belief to Sathoff. Internal investigation reports said Officer Israel Holsti, who stood next to Sathoff at the scene, also believed Clark was armed and trying to reach for a gun.

Day noted that a grand jury last year cleared Sathoff of criminal wrongdoing in the shooting. He said Sathoff remains with the Police Bureau in an “off-street capacity,” but did not say what Sathoff was doing. 

Four out of seven members of the Police Review Board, a mix of police employees and city residents that advise the chief, also believed Sathoff’s actions were in policy.

But Day’s explanation did not satisfy some city councilors. 

Councilor Loretta Smith questioned why he and city officials did not mention that Stacey Rovinelli, a police internal affairs investigator, ruled Sathoff had violated the deadly force policy. In an analysis, Rovinelli found no evidence to support that Clark had planned to stop running or intended to confront the officers.

Smith also pointed out that the robbery victim told dispatchers the suspects were all men and “definitely white.” Clark was Black, Smith said. The car he was driving had three passengers: another Black man, a white man and a white woman, according to the lawsuit filed by Clark’s family.

“The knowns were that the people they should have been looking for were white men, and Manny was not and he got shot [at] three times,” Smith said.

Councilors also asked why Clark didn’t get medical help sooner. The lawsuit stated that medics got to him about 26 minutes after he was shot.

Day said Thursday that officers were taking the other passengers in the car into custody and setting up a perimeter not knowing who might have guns or other weapons. Once they rounded up the passengers, they moved in on Clark, he said. 

Rovinelli wrote in her report that Sathoff saw Clark fall to the ground after he fired a third shot but did not report that Clark was down to anyone except Holsti. If he had, she said the response “could have been altered to render aid to (Clark) sooner.”

Councilor Mitch Green called the use of force in the case “unreasonable,” saying Sathoff had a long rifle with the benefit of a cover while Clark was running away from him.

“We cannot tolerate this anymore,” Green said. 

Councilor Angelita Morillo called the case a “massive injustice” and Councilor Candace Avalos said she was disturbed that the shooting was found to be in policy.

Avalos and Councilor Jamie Dunphy asked why the officer was not fired.

Many councilors offered apologies to Clark’s family and Pirtle-Guiney asked city public safety and police officials to look at how they can make sure a shooting like this doesn’t happen again.

Separately, city councilors voted unanimously to pay $62,500 to Hannah Ahern, who had sued a Portland detective, Erik Kammerer, and other unnamed officers, claiming they falsely arrested her at an August 2019 protest to get back at her for spitting in the direction of a police van earlier that day.

—Zaeem Shaikh covers the Portland Police Bureau and criminal justice issues for The Oregonian/OregonLive. Reach him at 503-221-4323, zshaikh@oregonian.com or on X@zaeemshake.

Separately, city councilors voted unanimously to pay $62,500 to Hannah Ahern, who had sued a Portland detective, Erik Kammerer, and other unnamed officers, claiming they falsely arrested her at an August 2019 protest to get back at her for spitting in the direction of a police van earlier that day.

—Zaeem Shaikh covers the Portland Police Bureau and criminal justice issues for The Oregonian/OregonLive. Reach him at 503-221-4323, zshaikh@oregonian.com or on X@zaeemshake.

images.alt:
Sad news today. Bithell Games, having been unable to secure a new larger scale project, is reducing in size. This means that eleven jobs are being made redundant. This constitutes the majority of our full-time staff.

It became clear leading up to the release of our most recent game that we were not immune to the challenges faced by many game development teams seeking funding partners in 2024 and 2025. We’ve fortunately been able to communicate these challenges ahead of time, and work with affected staff to ease departures as much as possible via severance packages.

It’s important to state that this was an incredible team of exceptionally talented people. If you’re a developer reading this, and you’re hiring; anyone among those affected would be a great addition to your studio, please reach out if we can help to put you in touch.

This news will not impact the availability of our existing self published games and ongoing support for them. We are incredibly grateful for our audience, and hope that your interest in our work follows individual team members as they head into other roles.

Bithell Games was always defined and elevated by our people. Today we 
are less.

-   Mike Bithell

It’s important to state that this was an incredible team of exceptionally talented people. If you’re a developer reading this, and you’re hiring; anyone among those affected would be a great addition to your studio, please reach out if we can help to put you in touch.

This news will not impact the availability of our existing self published games and ongoing support for them. We are incredibly grateful for our audience, and hope that your interest in our work follows individual team members as they head into other roles.

Bithell Games was always defined and elevated by our people. Today we 
are less.

-   Mike Bithell

record.text:
EHRC now saying that not only should trans people be excluded from sex segregated spaces, but ALSO those matching birth sex:

“A legitimate aim for excluding a trans person from … service for their own biological sex …to prevent alarm or distress for other service users.” 
archive.ph/2025.08.07-2...

images.alt:
The Times understands that the guidance is still being finalised and it will not decree that services have to provide single-sex spaces, but that if they do - for example if a lavatory is intended for women - transgender women would be excluded from using it. To allow someone of the opposite sex to use the facilities would be very likely to amount to unlawful discrimination.
It will also make clear that it will not be deemed as discrimination to exclude trans people from those facilities and that services will be allowed to request birth certificates to ensure single-sex services are protected.

It read: "A legitimate aim for excluding a trans person from a separate or single-sex service for their own biological sex might be to prevent alarm or distress for other service
users.
"A trans man might be excluded from the women-only service if the service provider decides that, because he presents as a man, other service users could reasonably object to his presence, and it is a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim to exclude him".

record.text:
I mean... yeah. Old-school conspiratorial crazy was both isolating and labor-intensive. You had to print zines and stuff.

But nowadays, the computer will happily provide you with both a community of like-minded nutters, and all the Grok-made evidence for your specific madness you could want.

So, interestingly enough, the "men don't read" thing seems to be a myth that's gone viral. Vox did a deep dive into the whole thing: www.vox.com/culture/3929...

Women *do* read more than men, but the difference seems to be on the order of 15% more, not multiples.

record.text: hm. I really do hope that someone is doing some kind of statistical study here. Because on the one hand, we've always had crazy people, they have merely found a new outlet for crazy. But on the other hand, it's at least *plausible* that ChatGPT is worse for accelerating crazy.

And it was that moment at 3.30am when The Chocolate Watchband came on my headphones that I decided to punch myself n the face and go to be d . Warm Saturdays tubby tubnuts breakfasts and jolly bafooning to you all. We’re all just passing the time X ❤️🖕💋

external.description: The earnings of farm laborers in the United States during a season depend on several factors, including the type of work, location, hours worked, and whether they are paid hourly or by piece rate. Since the term "season" can vary (typically 3–10 months depending on the crop or region), I’ll provide an estimate based on available data and clarify the assumptions.  Hourly Wage Data Average Hourly Wages (2025):   According to recent data, the average hourly wage for farm workers in the U.S. is approximately $17.41–$17.45 based on job market analyses.   PayScale reports a slightly lower average of $14.93 per hour in 2025, though this may reflect a broader range of roles or less experienced workers.   For H-2A visa workers (temporary agricultural workers), the Adverse Effect Wage Rate (AEWR), which sets a minimum wage for these workers, varies by state but averaged $13.68 per hour nationally in 2020, with 2025 rates likely higher due to inflation and wage trends.  Wage Range:   The hourly wage range for farm workers is typically $10.82–$26.20, with the majority earning between $14.90 (25th percentile) and $19.23 (75th percentile).   Higher wages are often seen in states like California or for specialized roles, while lower wages may apply in regions with less demand or for less skilled tasks.  Seasonal Earnings Estimate To estimate seasonal earnings, we need to make assumptions about the length of a season and hours worked: Season Length: A typical agricultural season for crops (e.g., fruit picking, vegetable harvesting) lasts about 3–6 months (12–24 weeks), though some H-2A workers may work up to 10 months. Hours Worked: Farm laborers often work 40–50 hours per week during peak seasons, though hours can vary due to weather or crop cycles. The USDA’s Farm Labor Survey suggests employers report average weekly hours, but specific figures for 2025 are not fully detailed here.  Calculation Using Average Wage ($17.43/hour, midpoint of $17.41–$17.45):   For a 3-month season (12 weeks) at 40 hours/week:       $17.43 × 40 hours × 12 weeks = $8,366.40   For a 6-month season (24 weeks) at 40 hours/week:       $17.43 × 40 hours × 24 weeks = $16,732.80   For a 10-month season (40 weeks) at 40 hours/week (e.g., H-2A workers):       $17.43 × 40 hours × 40 weeks = $27,888  Using Lower-End Wage ($14.93/hour):   For a 3-month season (12 weeks) at 40 hours/week:       $14.93 × 40 hours × 12 weeks = $7,166.40   For a 6-month season (24 weeks) at 40 hours/week:       $14.93 × 40 hours × 24 weeks = $14,332.80  Using Higher-End Wage ($19.23/hour, 75th percentile):   For a 3-month season (12 weeks) at 40 hours/week:       $19.23 × 40 hours × 12 weeks = $9,230.40   For a 6-month season (24 weeks) at 40 hours/week:       $19.23 × 40 hours × 24 weeks = $18,460.80  Piece Rate Considerations Some farm laborers are paid by piece rate (e.g., per basket of fruit picked), which can lead to higher or lower earnings depending on productivity. Data on piece rates is less standardized, but the USDA notes that piece-rate workers may earn more during peak harvest periods if they are highly efficient.  Additional Factors Regional Variations: Wages are higher in states like California (e.g., Soledad, CA, may see wages closer to $18/hour or more) due to higher costs of living and labor demand. H-2A Program: H-2A workers are guaranteed a state-specific minimum wage (AEWR), which may be higher than the federal minimum wage for farm workers ($7.25/hour as of 2025, though many states have higher minimums). Overtime and Benefits: Overtime pay (e.g., time-and-a-half for hours over 40/week) is not guaranteed for farm workers under federal law, though some states like California mandate it. Benefits like housing or transportation may be provided for H-2A workers, effectively increasing their compensation. Wage Trends: Farmworker wages have risen gradually over the past 30 years, both in real terms and relative to nonfarm wages, but they remain low compared to other industries. In 2020, farmworkers earned about 60% of comparable nonfarm workers’ wages.  Summary On average, farm laborers in the U.S. in 2025 can expect to earn: $7,000–$9,000 for a 3-month season (12 weeks, 40 hours/week). $14,000–$18,000 for a 6-month season (24 weeks, 40 hours/week). $22,000–$28,000 for a 10-month season (40 weeks, 40 hours/week, typical for H-2A workers).  These estimates assume a 40-hour workweek and use 2025 wage data. Actual earnings vary based on location, hours, piece-rate pay, and specific labor agreements. For more precise figures, you’d need to specify the crop, region, or whether the worker is part of the H-2A program. If you have more details (e.g., state or crop type), I can refine the estimate further!
external.title: How much do farm laborers make during a season?
